p: Hanada et al. reported the dehydrogenation of Ca(AlH 4) 2 + Si, Ca(AlH 4) 2 + 2MgH 2, Ca(AlH 4) 2 + 2LiH, and Ca(AlH 4) 2 + 2LiNH 2 mixtures that were produced by manual or ball milling [ 226]. In their work, Ca(AlH 4) 2 was produced by a metathesis reaction and it was used without purifying, i.e., with the load of NaCl. The weight losses were 6.1 wt.% for Ca(AlH 4) 2 + 2MgH 2 and 5.5 wt.% for manually milled Ca(AlH 4) 2 + 2LiNH 2. These values were reported without taking the load of NaCl into account. The rest of the hydrogen release values were not clearly specified. For the Ca(AlH 4) 2 + Si mixture, the first two reactions are the usual Ca(AlH 4) 2 dehydrogenation reactions, Si does not react with CaH 2 or Ca-containing phases [ 226]. For the Ca(AlH 4) 2 + 2MgH 2 mixture, after the usual first two dehydrogenation reactions, MgH 2 decomposes at around 270–350 °C and then reacts with Al to form Al 12Mg 17 [ 226]. Alapati et al., by means of first-principle calculations, arrived at the same reactions, plus a high-temperature reaction [ 227]: 6CaH 2 + Al 12Mg 17 → 17Mg + 6Al 2Ca + 6H 2 (~600 °C) (51)
